items.title: Prevent socket.inet_pton override on Python3
items.body:
I am using win_inet_pton for compatibility with Python 2.7. I am always getting a socket.error(ctypes.FormatError()) exception while running on windows 10 with Python3.4, 3.5 and 3.6. The Python 3 socket library on windows comes with the inet_pton and inet_ntop functions. Prevent overriding the default function for Python 3.

```python
# Adding our two functions to the socket library
if not hasattr(socket, 'inet_pton') and os.name == 'nt':
    socket.inet_pton = inet_pton
    socket.inet_ntop = inet_ntop
```

items.title: 1.0.1 PKG-INFO is malformed
items.body:
The PKG-INFO file in the 1.0.1 release tarball on PyPI is malformed:

```
Metadata-Version: 1.1
Name: win_inet_pton
Version: 1.0.1
Summary: Native inet_pton and inet_ntop implementation for Python on Windows (with ctypes).
Home-page: https://github.com/hickeroar/win_inet_pton
Author: Ryan Vennell
Author-email: ryan.vennell@gmail.com
License: This software released into the public domain. Anyone is free to copy,
modify, publish, use, compile, sell, or distribute this software,
either in source code form or as a compiled binary, for any purpose,
commercial or non-commercial, and by any means.
Description: UNKNOWN
Platform: UNKNOWN
Classifier: Development Status :: 5 - Production/Stable
Classifier: Intended Audience :: Developers
Classifier: Operating System :: OS Independent
Classifier: Operating System :: Microsoft :: Windows
Classifier: Programming Language :: Python :: 2.7
Classifier: Topic :: Utilities
```

Note the lack of indentation after the `License:` line. Those continuation lines should have leading whitespace as this file is in RFC 822 format. See [the example in PEP 314](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0314/#license).

You can probably fix this by using setuptools to generate the sdist rather than distutils.

items.title: inet_pton accepts invalid IPv4 addresses
items.body:
Expected results (python 2.7.12 on Mac OS X 10.10.5):
```python
>>> import socket
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192')))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
socket.error: illegal IP address string passed to inet_pton
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192.168')))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
socket.error: illegal IP address string passed to inet_pton
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192.168.1')))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
socket.error: illegal IP address string passed to inet_pton
>>>
```

Actual results (python 2.7.12 on Windows 7 Pro SP1):
```python
>>> import socket
>>> import win_inet_pton
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192')))
0.0.0.192
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192.168')))
192.0.0.168
>>> print(socket.inet_ntop(socket.AF_INET, socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, '192.168.1')))
192.168.0.1
>>>
```

I could also handle a compromise where a partial IPv4 address always filled in octets left-to-right: "192" => "192.0.0.0", "192.168" => "192.168.0.0", "192.168.1" => "192.168.1.0"

items.title: Fails with Unicode string
items.body:
```
Python 2.7.9 (default, Dec 10 2014, 12:24:55) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import win_inet_pton
>>> s = u'::1'
>>> import socket
>>> socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET6, s)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "J:\dev\workspace\pythonxy-xy-27\src\python\jsonschema\__workspace__\jsonschema-git\.tox\py27\lib\site-packages\win_inet_pton.py", line 42, in inet_pton
    raise socket.error(ctypes.FormatError())
>>> socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET6, '::1')
'\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x01'

```
